title: Week 2 (Slides) - Cognitive Perspectives and Introduction to ggplot2

yaml.title: Week 2 (Slides) - Cognitive Perspectives and Introduction to ggplot2
yaml.author: Emorie D Beck

markdown.headingText: Part 1: Good/Bad Data Visualizations and Reading Discussion
markdown.markdown:
```{r} library(plyr) library(tidyverse) ``` ## The cognitive and psychological foundation of data visualization ::::: {.columns .v-center-container} ::: {.column width="50%"} - We are better at processing visual information than verbal information (includes reading)? Yes! - Why? Preattentive processing ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ```{r, fig.align='center'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/info-proc.jpeg") ``` ::: ::::: ## Visual Variables ::::: columns ::: column - Position (x; y) - Size (size) - Shape (shape; linetype) - Lightness (color; fill) - Color hue (color; fill) - Orientation (angle) ::: ::: column - Texture (linetype; shape) - Color saturation (color; fill) - Arrangement (scale\_\[mapping\]\_\[type\]) - Crispness (e.g., geom_point v. geom_jitter) - Resolution (ggsave) - Transparency (alpha) ::: ::::: ## 6 Common Types of Visual Aesthetics ```{r, fig.align='center'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/vis-vars.png") ``` ## Gestalt Principles - Gestalt psychology emerges from the observation that we perceive elements of the world holistically - Can be leveraged to allow simple perceptions of complex patterns ## Gestalt Principles ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt-list.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt-proximity.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt-closure.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt-similarity.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt-figure-ground.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt-symmetry.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/gestalt-continuity.png") ``` ## The Cognitive Psychology of Data Visualization ### Principles for Efficient Visualization 1. Use visualizations to allow viewers to powerfully compute statistics 2. Avoid visual processing limits: making comparisons 3. Control comparison with visual grouping cues 4. Guide viewer to the most important comparison 5. Avoid taxing limited working memory ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-1.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-2a.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-2b.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-2c.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-2d.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-3a.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-3b.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-3c.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-3d.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-4.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-4b.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-4c.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-5a.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-5b.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ```{r, fig.align='center', out.width='100%'} knitr::include_graphics("03-images/prin-5c.png") ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::::: {.columns .v-center-container} ::: {.column width="70%"}

Visualizing Data in `ggplot2`

::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ```{r, fig.align='center'} knitr::include_graphics("https://github.com/rstudio/hex-stickers/raw/main/thumbs/ggplot2.png") ``` ::: ::::: ## What is ggplot2 trying to do? - Create a grammar of graphics - Aims to help draw connections across diverse plots - Create order in the chaos of complicated plots ::: fragment From Wickham (2010): > A grammar of graphics is a tool that enables us to concisely describe the components of a graphic. ::: ## What are the core elements of ggplot2 grammar? - **Mappings**: base layer - **Scales**: control and modify your mappings - **Geoms**: plot elements - **Facets**: panel your plot - **Grobs**: things that aren't geoms that we want to layer on like text, arrows, other things - **Themes**: style your figure ## But first, our data :::::: columns ::: column - These are some Experience Sampling Method data I collected during my time in graduate school - Specifically, these include data from Beck & Jackson (2022) - In that paper I built personalized machine learning models of behaviors and experiences from sets of: - psychological - situational - and time variables ::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T} load(url("https://github.com/emoriebeck/psc290-data-viz-2022/raw/main/02-week2-ggplot2/01-data/ipcs_data.RData")) ipcs_data %>% print(n = 6) ``` ```{r} ipcs_data <- ipcs_data %>% group_by(SID) %>% mutate(beep = 1:n()) %>% ungroup() ``` ::: :::: :::::: ## Mappings :::::: columns ::: column - The first thing we call with `ggplot2` is always the `ggplot()` function, which has two core arguments: - `data`: your data object (can also be piped)\ ::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, fig.dim= c(7,3.5)} ggplot( data = ipcs_data ) ``` ::: :::: :::::: ## Mappings ::::::: columns :::: column ::: nonincremental - The first thing we call with `ggplot2` is always the `ggplot()` function, which has two core arguments: - `data`: your data object (can also be piped)\ - `mapping`: you aesthetic mappings for the plot, wrapped in `aes()` ::: :::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} ggplot( data = ipcs_data , mapping = aes(x = linear, y = happy) ) ``` ::: :::: ::::::: ## Mappings - How many aesthetic mappings are there? ::::: columns ::: column - `x` - `y` - `col` / `color` - `fill` - `shape` ::: ::: column - `size` - `linetype` - `xmin` / `xmax` - `ymin` / `ymax` - `alpha` ::: ::::: - There are lots of geom-specific ones, too - Use ?geom_whatever() to get more info on a specific geom ## Scales - Every mapping is a scale - Scales can be lots of different things - In ggplot2 language, some core ones are: ::::: columns ::: column - `continuous` - `discrete` - `manual` - `ordinal` ::: ::: column - `binned` - `date` - `brewer` ::: ::::: - All of these have specific arguments based on the type of scale ## Scales ### `continuous` :::::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} - Let's try the `continuous` scale with our `y` mapping - We'll use the following three arguments - `limits`: vector length 2 - `breaks`: vector of any length - `labels`: numeric or character vector ::: :::: {.column width="60"} ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center',fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} ggplot( data = ipcs_data , mapping = aes(x = linear, y = happy) ) + scale_y_continuous( limits = c(1, 5) , breaks = seq(1, 5, by = 2) , labels = c("one", "three", "five") ) ``` ::: :::: :::::: ## Geoms ::::: columns ::: column - We'll loop back to scales after talking about some geoms - It's not possible to go through all the possible geoms (that's what the rest of the class is for!) - We'll focus on some basic ones for now ::: ::: column - `geom_point()` - `geom_jitter()` - `geom_smooth()` - `geom_hline()` / `geom_vline()` - `geom_bar()` - `geom_boxplot()` - `geom_density()` - `geom_histogram()` ::: ::::: ## Geoms: `geom_point()` Your basic scatterplot! ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy )) + geom_point() + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.show='show', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy )) + geom_point() + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::::: ## Geoms: `geom_point()` Your basic scatterplot! ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy , color = happy )) + geom_point() + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.show='show', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy , color = happy )) + geom_point() + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::::: ## Geoms: `geom_point()` {.smaller} Your basic scatterplot! :::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, out.height="50%", fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} #| code-line-numbers: "8" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy , color = happy )) + scale_color_continuous(type = "viridis") + geom_point() + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, out.height="50%", fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} #| code-line-numbers: "8" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy , color = happy )) + scale_color_gradient(low = "red", high = "blue") + geom_point() + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: :::::: ## Geoms: `geom_jitter()` :::::: columns ::: column - Sometimes we have data that have lots of repeating values, especially with ordinal response scales where the variables aren't composited / latent - jitter adds random noise to the point to allow you to see more of the points ::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy )) + geom_jitter() + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: :::::: This may be too much jitter ## Geoms: `geom_jitter()` :::::: columns :::: column ::: nonincremental - Sometimes we have data that have lots of repeating values, especially with ordinal response scales where the variables aren't composited / latent - jitter adds random noise to the point to allow you to see more of the points ::: :::: ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes( x = purposeful , y = happy )) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::::: ## Geoms: `geom_jitter()` {.smaller} ### `alpha` ::::: columns ::: column Alpha can help us understand how many points are stacked when using jitter (or other overlapping data) ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show='show', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} #| code-line-numbers: "|7" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter( width = .1 , height = .1 , alpha = .25 ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::::: ## Geoms: `geom_smooth()` - `geom_smooth()` allows you to apply statistical functions to your data - There are other ways to do this that we won't cover today - Core arguments are: - `method`: "loess", "lm", "glm", "gam" - `formula`: e.g., `y ~ x` or `y ~ poly(x, 2)` - `se`: display standard error of estimate (`T`/ `F`) - `aes()` wrapped aesthetics or directly mapped aesthetics ## Geoms: `geom_smooth()` {.smaller} Remember: it's a **LAYERED** grammar of graphics, so let's layer! ::::::: columns :::: column ::: fragment #### `method = "lm"` ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "|5-9" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = F , color = "blue" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: :::: column ::: fragment #### `method = "loess"` ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-9" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "loess" , formula = y ~ x , se = F , color = "blue" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: ::::::: ## Geoms: `geom_smooth()` {.smaller} Remember: it's a **LAYERED** grammar of graphics, so let's layer! ::::::: columns :::: column ::: fragment #### `method = "lm"` ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-9" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: :::: column ::: fragment #### `method = "loess"` ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-9" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "loess" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: ::::::: ## Geoms: ### `geom_hline()`/`geom_vline()` - Sometimes, we will want to place lines at various intercepts - We'll get into specific use cases as the course progresses - `geom_hline()`: horizontal lines have `yintercept` mappings - `geom_vline()`: vertical lines have `xintercept` mappings ## Geoms: {.smaller} ### `geom_hline()`/`geom_vline()` ::::::: columns :::: column `geom_hline()`: horizontal lines have `yintercept` mappings ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-8" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_hline( aes(yintercept = mean(happy, na.rm = T)) , linetype = "dashed" ) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x, se = F, color = "blue") + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: :::: column `geom_vline()`: vertical lines have `xintercept` mappings ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-8" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_vline( aes(xintercept = mean(purposeful, na.rm = T)) , linetype = "dashed" ) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x, se = F, color = "blue") + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: ::::::: ## Geoms: `geom_line()` :::::: columns ::: column - Line graphs are great for showing relationships among variables as well as showing changes over time - Be careful, `geom_line()` in `ggplot2` is pretty literal - We'll come back to this several times, so I'll just show one example of a time series ::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|4" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = beep, y = happy)) + geom_line(color = "blue") + geom_point(size = 1) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: :::: :::::: ## Geoms: `geom_bar()` - Bar graphs can be useful for showing relative differences - My hot take is that they are rarely that useful - (This is mostly because of how we perceive errorbars and differences, which we'll talk more about in a few weeks!) - But let's look at using them for frequency and means / se's ## Geoms: `geom_bar()` ### Frequency How often did our participant have an argument, interact with others, study, and feel tired? :::::: fragment ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show = 'hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, Full_Date, argument, interacted, study, tired) %>% pivot_longer( cols = argument:tired , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" , values_drop_na = T ) %>% group_by(item) %>% summarize(value = sum(value == 1)) %>% ggplot(aes(x = item, fill = item, y = value)) + geom_col(color = "black") + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, Full_Date, argument, interacted, study, tired) %>% pivot_longer( cols = argument:tired , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" , values_drop_na = T ) %>% group_by(item) %>% summarize(value = sum(value == 1)) %>% ggplot(aes(x = item, fill = item, y = value)) + geom_col(color = "black") + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: :::::: ## Geoms: `geom_bar()` {.smaller} ### Mean differences Were there mean-level in our continuous variables? :::::: fragment ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show = 'hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|3-9|10-14|16|17-22" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" , values_drop_na = T ) %>% group_by(item) %>% summarize( mean = mean(value) , ci = 1.96*(sd(value)/sqrt(n())) ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = item, fill = item, y = mean)) + geom_col(color = "black") + geom_errorbar( aes(ymin = mean - ci, ymax = mean + ci) , position = position_dodge(width = .1) , width = .1 , stat = "identity" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" , values_drop_na = T ) %>% group_by(item) %>% summarize( mean = mean(value) , ci = 1.96*(sd(value)/sqrt(n())) ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = item, fill = item, y = mean)) + geom_col(color = "black") + geom_errorbar( aes(ymin = mean - ci, ymax = mean + ci) , position = position_dodge(width = .1) , width = .1 , stat = "identity" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: :::::: ## Geoms: `geom_boxplot()` - Sometimes called box and whisker plots - A method for summarizing a distribution of data without showing raw data - Box instead shows 25th, 50th, and 75th percentile (quartiles) - Whiskers show 1.5 \* interquartile range (75%tile-25%tile) - More fun when we want to compare distributions across variables (IMO) ## Geoms: `geom_boxplot()` ### One boxplot ```{r , echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "4" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(aes(y = SID, x = happy)) + geom_boxplot(width = .5) + theme_classic() ``` ## Geoms: `geom_boxplot()` ### Multiple boxplots :::::: columns ::::: fragment ::: column - We can compare multiple participants - Later, we'll also talk about how to order the boxplots (and other axes) by means, medians, etc. ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "|5" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216", "211", "174", "150", "171")) %>% ggplot(aes( y = SID, x = happy , fill = SID )) + geom_boxplot(width = .5) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F,fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216", "211", "174", "150", "171")) %>% ggplot(aes( y = SID, x = happy , fill = SID )) + geom_boxplot(width = .5) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: :::::: ## Geoms: `geom_boxplot()` {.smaller} ### Multiple boxplots - We can also compare multiple variables :::::: fragment ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} #| code-line-numbers: "|5-8|10,12" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes( y = item , x = value , fill = item )) + geom_boxplot(width = .5) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes( y = item , x = value , fill = item )) + geom_boxplot(width = .5) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: :::::: ## Geoms: `geom_boxplot()` {.smaller} ### Advanced! ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "4-14" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1,7), breaks = seq(1,5,2)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(1,7), breaks = seq(1,5,2)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_boxplot(aes( x = 6 , y = happy )) + geom_boxplot(aes( y = 6 , x = purposeful )) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = F , color = "blue" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-8" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1,7), breaks = seq(1,5,2)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(1,7), breaks = seq(1,5,2)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_boxplot(aes(x = 6, y = happy)) + geom_boxplot(aes(y = 6, x = purposeful)) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x, se = F, color = "blue") + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::::: ## Geoms: {.smaller} ### `geom_histogram()` & `geom_density()` - Useful for showing raw / smoothed distributions of data ::::::: columns :::: column ::: fragment #### Histogram ```{r , echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "4-7" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(aes(y = happy)) + geom_histogram( fill = "grey" , color = "black" ) + coord_flip() + theme_classic() ``` ::: :::: :::: column ::: fragment #### Density Distribution ```{r , echo = T, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "4-7" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(aes(x = happy, y = ..density..)) + geom_histogram( fill = "grey" , color = "black" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: :::: ::::::: ## Geoms: {.smaller} ### `geom_histogram()` & `geom_density()` ### Multiple histograms / density distributions - We can compare multiple participants :::::: fragment ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|5" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216", "211", "174", "150", "171")) %>% ggplot(aes( y = happy , fill = SID )) + geom_density(alpha = .2) + coord_flip() + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F,fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216", "211", "174", "150", "171")) %>% ggplot(aes( y = happy , fill = SID )) + geom_density(alpha = .2) + coord_flip() + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: :::::: # Plot Appearance Beyond Mappings: Facets and Themes ## Plot Appearance - So far, we have only changed appearance via the `scale_()` functions - But that doesn't change things like axis, text, title, and more - Nor does it help when we want to split the plot into multiple panels - Let's do those next! ## Plot Apperance: Facets :::::: columns ::: column - Often, we have lots of other reasons we need to reproduce the same plot multiple times - multiple variables - multiple people - multiple conditions - etc. - There are more ways to do this than we'll cover today, like piecing plots together and more ::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = F,fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,5)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216", "211", "174", "150")) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = happy, group = SID)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_wrap(~SID, ncol = 1) + theme_classic() ``` ::: :::: :::::: ## Appearance: Facets :::::: columns ::: column - The core of directly faceting within ggplot is that you have to facet according to variables in your data set - This is part of why we covered moving your data to long - Say that you want to facet by variable, for example, but your data is in wide form - Facets couldn't handle that ::: :::: column ::: fragment ```{r, echo = T} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% print(n = 8) ``` ::: :::: :::::: ## Appearance: Facets - In `ggplot2`, there are two core faceting functions - `facet_grid()` - `facet_wrap()` ::::: columns ::: column - `facet_grid()` - snaps figures in a grid; no wrapping - especially useful for 1-2 faceting variables ::: ::: column - `facet_wrap()` - treats each facet a separate - wraps according to `nrow` and `ncol` arguments ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Facets {.smaller} ::::: columns ::: column ### `facet_grid()` Core arguments: - `rows`, `cols`: list of variables or formula, e.g., `x ~ y` - `scales`: same x or y scale on all facets? - `space`: same space for unequal length x or y facets? - `switch`: move labels from left to right or top to bottom? - `drop`: drop unused factor levels ::: ::: column ### `facet_wrap()` Core arguments: - `facets`: barequoted or one-sided formula, e.g., `~ x + y` - `nrow` / `ncol`: number of rows and columns - `scales`: same x or y scale on all facets? - `switch`: move labels from left to right or top to bottom? - `drop`: drop unused factor levels - `dir`: horizontal or vertical - `strip.position`: where to put the labels ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Facets ### `facet_grid()` ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center'} #| code-line-numbers: "|12" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_grid(item~.) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4), out.width="100%"} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_grid(item~.) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Facets ### `facet_wrap()` ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center'} #| code-line-numbers: "|12-16" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_wrap( ~item , ncol = 1 , strip.position = "right" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4), out.width="100%"} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_wrap( ~item , ncol = 1 , strip.position = "right" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Facets ### `facet_wrap()`: Change scale and space ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center'} #| code-line-numbers: "|12-16" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_grid( item ~ . , scales = "free_y" , space = "free_y" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4), out.width="100%"} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_grid( item ~ . , scales = "free_y" , space = "free_y" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Labels & Titles - APA style says titles are bad - Common sense says titles help understanding - Ask for forgiveness, not permission ## Appearance: Labels & Titles Remember this? ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show = 'hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-9" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "5-9" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Labels & Titles ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show = 'hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|11-15" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + labs( x = "Momentary Purpose (1-5)" , y = "Momentary Happiness (1-5)" , title = "Zero-Order Associations Between Momentary Happiness and Purpose" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|11-15" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + labs( x = "Momentary Purpose (1-5)" , y = "Momentary Happiness (1-5)" , title = "Zero-Order Associations Between Momentary Happiness and Purpose" ) + theme_classic() # I just hate grey backgrounds ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Labels & Titles Labels also apply to other mappings like color ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|9-13" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216", "211", "174", "150", "171")) %>% ggplot(aes( y = happy , fill = SID )) + geom_density(alpha = .2) + coord_flip() + labs( x = "Momentary Happiness" , y = "Smoothed Density" , fill = "Participant\nID" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F,fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4), out.width="100%"} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216", "211", "174", "150", "171")) %>% ggplot(aes( y = happy , fill = SID )) + geom_density(alpha = .2) + coord_flip() + labs( x = "Momentary Happiness" , y = "Smoothed Density" , fill = "Participant\nID" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Labels & Titles You can also use labels to **remove** axis labels ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|5-8|15-19" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes( y = item , x = value , fill = item )) + geom_boxplot(width = .5) + labs( x = "Momentart Rating (1-5)" , y = NULL , fill = "Item" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes( y = NULL , x = value , fill = item )) + labs( x = "Momentart Rating (1-5)" , y = NULL , fill = "Item" ) + geom_boxplot(width = .5) + theme_classic() ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Themes (Basic) - There are lots of themes you can use in ggplot that are pre-built into the package - Try tying `theme_` into your R console, and look at the functions that pop up - Some stand-out ones are: - `theme_classic()` (what we've been using) - `theme_bw()` - `theme_minimal()` (but is there a theme_maximal?) - `theme_void` ## Appearance: Themes (Advanced) - Custom themes are one of the best ways to "hack" your ggplots - You will not remember all of them - You will have to google them all time - Here's the site: - Rather than give details on a bunch of these, I'm going to demonstrate theme modifications I often use ## Appearance: Themes {.smaller} ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show = 'hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(4,2.75)} #| code-line-numbers: "17-31" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + labs( x = "Momentary Purpose (1-5)" , y = "Momentary Happiness (1-5)" , title = "Zero-Order Associations Between Momentary Happiness and Purpose" ) + theme_classic() + theme( plot.title = element_text( face = "bold" , size = rel(1.1) , hjust = .5 ) , axis.title = element_text( face = "bold" , size = rel(1.1) ) , axis.text = element_text( face = "bold" , size = rel(1.2) ) ) ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} #| code-line-numbers: "|11-15" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = purposeful, y = happy)) + geom_jitter(width = .1, height = .1, alpha = .25) + geom_smooth( method = "lm" , formula = y ~ x , se = T , color = "blue" ) + labs( x = "Momentary Purpose (1-5)" , y = "Momentary Happiness (1-5)" , title = "Zero-Order Associations Between Momentary Happiness and Purpose" ) + theme_classic() + theme( plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1), hjust = .5) , axis.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1)) , axis.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.2)) ) ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Themes {.smaller} ::::: columns ::: column ```{r, echo = T, fig.show = 'hide', fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(5,3.5)} #| code-line-numbers: "|23-27|29-34" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" , values_drop_na = T ) %>% group_by(item) %>% summarize( mean = mean(value) , ci = 1.96*(sd(value)/sqrt(n())) ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = item, fill = item, y = mean)) + geom_col(color = "black") + geom_errorbar( aes(ymin = mean - ci, ymax = mean + ci) , position = position_dodge(width = .1) , width = .1 , stat = "identity" ) + labs( x = NULL , y = "Mean Momentary Rating (CI)\n[Range 1-5]" , title = "Descriptive Statistics of Momentary Emotion Ratings" ) + theme_classic() + theme( legend.position = "none" , plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1), hjust = .5) , axis.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1)) , axis.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.2)) ) ``` ::: ::: column ```{r, echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,4)} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID %in% c("216")) %>% select(SID, Full_Date, happy, purposeful, afraid, attentive) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-SID, -Full_Date) , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" , values_drop_na = T ) %>% group_by(item) %>% summarize( mean = mean(value) , ci = 1.96*(sd(value)/sqrt(n())) ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = item, fill = item, y = mean)) + geom_col(color = "black") + geom_errorbar( aes(ymin = mean - ci, ymax = mean + ci) , position = position_dodge(width = .1) , width = .1 , stat = "identity" ) + labs( x = NULL , y = "Mean Momentary Rating (CI)\n[Range 1-5]" , title = "Descriptive Statistics of Momentary Emotion Ratings" ) + theme_classic() + theme( legend.position = "none" , plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1), hjust = .5) , axis.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1)) , axis.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.2)) ) ``` ::: ::::: ## Appearance: Themes {.smaller} ::::: columns ::: column ```{r , echo = T, fig.show='hide', fig.align='center'} #| code-line-numbers: "|13-18|20-29|21-22|26-27" ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_line(aes(color = item)) + geom_point(size = 1) + facet_grid(item~.) + labs( x = "ESM Beep (#)" , y = "Rated Momentary Value (1-5)" , title = "Time Series of Four Momentary Emotion Items for Participant 216" , color = NULL ) + theme_classic() + theme( legend.position = "bottom" , legend.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1)) , plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1), hjust = .5) , axis.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1)) , axis.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.2)) , strip.background = element_rect(color = "black", fill = "cornflowerblue") , strip.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.2), color = "white") ) ``` ::: ::: column ```{r , echo = F, fig.align='center', fig.dim= c(6,6), out.width="100%"} ipcs_data %>% filter(SID == "216") %>% select(SID, beep, afraid:content) %>% pivot_longer( cols = afraid:content , names_to = "item" , values_to = "value" ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = beep, y = value, group = item)) + geom_line(aes(color = item)) + geom_point(size = 1) + facet_grid(item~.) + labs( x = "ESM Beep (#)" , y = "Rated Momentary Value (1-5)" , title = "Time Series of Four Momentary Emotion Items for Participant 216" , color = NULL ) + theme_classic() + theme( legend.position = "bottom" , legend.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1)) , plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1), hjust = .5) , axis.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.1)) , axis.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.2)) , strip.background = element_rect(color = "black", fill = "cornflowerblue") , strip.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = rel(1.2), color = "white") ) ``` ::: ::::: ::::: columns ::: column ::: ::: column ::: :::::

metadata.title: Week 2 (Slides) - Cognitive Perspectives and Introduction to ggplot2
metadata.author: Emorie D Beck
